In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Asia and the Pacific is highly vulnerable to the adverse impacts of climate change. It 
contains more people at risk than any other region of the world. This places the need to address 
climate  change  firmly  on  the  region's  economic  development  agenda.  Continued  poverty 
reduction in Asia and the Pacific will not be possible without proactive efforts to mitigate the 
causes of global warming and help the region to adapt to the impacts of climate change, 
especially as they affect the most vulnerable; the poor, women, children and the elderly.  
 
2.  The great diversity of conditions across Asia and the Pacific will require differentiated 
responses based on the degree and type of each country’s vulnerability, its energy sector, and 
the carbon intensity of its economy. There will be an enormous need to finance mitigation and 
adaptation measures as well as knowledge products in a range of sectors and thematic areas.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB identified environmentally sustainable growth and especially climate change as a 
core area for ADB operations in its Strategy 2020.1 In April 2010, Management approved a 
paper that identified five strategic priorities for climate change in the region and described how 
ADB will support its developing member countries (DMCs) in addressing these five priorities.2 
The paper provides a coherent direction for ADB's climate change program. The strategic 
directions outlined in the paper now need to be implemented.  
 
4.  The major issues identified in the paper are as follows. 
 
(i)  Virtually all of ADB's DMCs have prepared national climate change action plans 
and related documents, a clear sign of the importance they assign to climate 
change in national economic development. However, a daunting array of policy, 
governance and capacity development challenges face these countries as they 
proceed to mainstream climate change programs. These challenges cut across 
all aspects of climate change action, and must be addressed as overarching 
components of support to DMCs. 
(ii)  If current patterns continue, Asia is projected to account for about 45% of global 
energy-related emissions by 2030. A massive shift toward clean energy will be 
needed, and ADB should be ready to scale up its already substantial support in 
this area. The main challenge to scaling up clean energy in the region is linking 
the  strong  pipeline  of  clean  energy  projects  and  programs  with  sources  of 
adequate funding. Recent reports by the Secretary General of the United Nations 
indicate  that,  for  energy  efficiency  alone,  annual  investments  of  $30 billion–
$35 billion are needed for low-income countries and $140 billion–$170 billion for 
middle-income countries.3  
(iii)  Asia's cities are the world’s single largest contributor of new greenhouse gas 
emissions, with associated adverse health, traffic congestion, water supply and 
other problems. Transport is the fastest growing source of these emissions. More 
sustainable  transport  and  urban  development  are  needed  to  avoid  further

massive environmental and economic costs and to bring about clean air, safer 
roads and generally more livable cities. 
(iv)  A recent ADB report4 indicated that up to 75% of Southeast Asia's greenhouse 
gas emissions are caused by land use change, especially deforestation. This is 
true of other countries in the region, particularly several Pacific DMCs. ADB 
acknowledges  the  need  to  take  focused  remedial  action  together  with 
development partners. 
(v)  Asia and the Pacific is home to the largest population at risk from climate change, 
so a vast expansion of adaptation measures is urgently needed. As the effects 
on water supply, staple crops, health, livelihoods and quality of life generally 
become more intense and widespread, it will be the poor, women and other 
vulnerable  segments  of  society  that  are  hit  the  hardest.  Promoting  climate 
resilience is an integral part of development for all countries in the region.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
5.  This will be an interdepartmental cluster technical assistance (TA) with subprojects at 
interregional,  regional,  national  and  subnational  levels  to  be  implemented  by  various 
departments in ADB. It will help DMCs to build climate change and disaster risk reduction in 
vulnerable sectors and mitigate greenhouse gas emissions of highly polluting sectors through 
capacity building, knowledge sharing and the generation of project concepts for adaptation and 
mitigation interventions. It will facilitate investment by the private sector and involvement by civil 
society.  
 
6.  The cluster approach is proposed because it will (i) ensure that ADB's climate change 
activities are cohesive and coordinated and in line with Addressing Climate Change in Asia and 
the Pacific: Priorities for Action, and (ii) serve as a vehicle to attract broad as well as issue-
specific co-financing from bilateral, multilateral and private funding sources. All of the TA's 
proposed and future sub-projects will respond to the five priority areas identified in Addressing 
Climate Change in Asia and the Pacific: Priorities for Action. Below, each of the currently 
proposed subprojects are listed alongside the corresponding strategic priority. The outcomes of 
individual subprojects are explained in brief here, and the outputs are outlined in paragraph 10. 
 
(i)  Strengthening  policies,  governance  and  capacities.  Two  cross-cutting 
subprojects are being designed: (i) Capacity Development to Address Climate 
Change by the Climate Change Program Coordination Unit in the Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department (RSDD-CC), to strengthen participating 
DMCs' and development practitioners' capacity to apply best available climate 
change knowledge to development planning (para. 10), and (ii) Developing and 
Applying Low-Carbon Development Policy Analysis Tools by the Economics and 
Research Department (ERD) to enhance the low-carbon planning capacity of 
national agencies and institutions through models and road maps for low-carbon 
growth. A third subproject, which will provide support for civil society involvement 
in climate change action, will be designed later for implementation in this priority 
area. 
(ii)  Expanding the use of clean energy. A subproject is being prepared by RSDD-
CC for approval in the third quarter of 2010 to develop mechanisms that can 
leverage large-scale private sector investment in clean energy in DMCs.  
                                                
4 ADB. 2009. Economics of Climate Change in Southeast Asia: A Regional Review. Manila.

3 
(iii)  Encouraging sustainable transport and urban development. Subprojects will 
be led by the Sustainable Infrastructure Division in RSDD (RSID). They will begin 
in 2011 or 2012 when the results of ongoing work and the requirements for 
follow-on support become known. 
(iv)  Managing land use and forests for carbon sequestration. Subprojects will 
build  on  existing  projects,  supporting  payment  for  ecosystem  services  and 
building capacity to reduce emissions from deforestation and forest degradation. 
It is expected that a subproject will be proposed in 2011 by RSDD-CC. 
(v)  Promoting  climate-resilient  development.  Three  subprojects  are  currently 
being prepared: (i) Build Resilience to Disaster and Climate Change Impacts by 
the Environment and Safeguards Division in RSDD (para. 10), (ii) Supporting 
Investments in Water and Climate Change, and (iii) a subproject to create an 
integrated disaster risk management model incorporating disaster risk financing, 
disaster  risk  management,  and  climate  change  adaptation  by  the  Public 
Management, Governance and Participation Division of RSDD (RSGP) for the 
third quarter of 2010.  
 
7.  The cluster TA will be coordinated with other TA projects and investment projects related 
to  climate  change,5 including  those  financed  by  the  Climate  Investment  Funds,  Global 
Environment Facility and other international climate programs. 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome  
 
8.   The TA impact will be that participating governments will increase appropriate responses 
to climate change and disasters with support from civil society and the private sector. The 
outcome will be that participating governments are able to integrate climate change and disaster 
responses with social and economic development goals. The overall design and monitoring 
framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.   The  cluster  TA  will  build  on  a  range  of  ADB  experience,  particularly  that  of  the 
operations departments, in supporting capacity development for climate change responses at 
regional, national and subnational levels in ADB’s five strategic priority areas. ADB will support 
scientific,  economic  and  social  impact  assessments  of  climate  and  disaster  risk  to  guide 
policymakers and regulators in responding to climate change. Through this TA, ADB will provide 
governments with better scientific and economic data at national and subnational levels to assist 
decision-making. The TA will provide support for community, social and physical-science-based 
impact  maps,  geographic  information  system  (GIS)  data,  climate  modeling  and  economic 
analysis on comparative costs of climate responses. Participating governments will be able to 
identify strategies for climate change and disaster risk reduction response and build related 
institutional capacity. A methodology will be developed to ensure government and civil society 
organization approaches are combined. This will enable participating countries to make more 
use of civil society to implement community-based mitigation and adaptation initiatives and to 
assess social impacts of climate change. The TA will stimulate greater private sector financing 
for climate change mitigation and adaptation activities.

Technical Assistance for Strengthening the Capacity of Pacific DMCs to Respond to Climate Change; several

Pacific and South Asia; and other work related to water, food and health security.

4     
 
 
10.  Described below are the three subprojects submitted at this time for approval under the 
TA cluster. 6 Subsequent subprojects of the TA will be determined by ADB, adopting a demand-
driven approach within the five priority areas. 
. 
(i)   Capacity  Development  to  Address  Climate  Change.  This  subproject  will 
strengthen participating DMCs' and development practitioners' capacity to apply 
the best available climate change knowledge to development planning. It will 
have four components: (i) achieving development and climate change results, 
which will develop a set of indicators to provide a consistent assessment of 
climate-related investments and a plan for their application; (ii) climate change 
capacity  development  for  policymakers,  regulators  and  development 
professionals  covering  both  government  and  civil  society  approaches;  (iii)  a 
climate atlas, which will summarize data from ongoing analyses by ADB and 
partners using an online platform; and (iv) applying development communications 
to improve climate responses, which will support climate change operational 
communications and knowledge management.  
(ii)   Build Resilience to Disaster and Climate Change Impacts. This subproject 
will  (i)  integrate  climate  resilience  considerations  into  national  and  sector 
planning  processes;  (ii)  address  policy,  research  and  knowledge  gaps  to 
enhance climate resilience at sector and project levels; (iii) help DMCs build 
climate resilience through  investment planning  which reduces climate risk to 
projects;  and  (iv)  strengthen  DMC  and  ADB  capacity  to  build  and  promote 
climate resilience. It will provide resources for pilot interventions that will help 
integrate climate resilience into country partnership strategies, sector road maps 
and projects at risk from climate change. These pilot interventions will include 
preparation of climate impact studies and vulnerability assessments, economic 
analyses of climate impacts and responses, development of tools and methods 
for climate proofing vulnerable infrastructure and investments and provision of 
technical assistance to DMC agencies.  
(iii)   Supporting Investments in Water and Climate Change. This subproject will 
improve  climate  change  projections  for  water  management,  and  impact 
assessments and adaptation strategies for selected river basins and projects in 
these basins, with guidelines and advice to policy and decision makers. It will 
include close engagement with project and river basin managers, scientists and 
knowledge  managers.  Knowledge  will  be  disseminated  to  leaders  through  a 
steering group of select policymakers, regulators and civil society representatives.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The estimated total cost of the initial three subprojects is $3.25 million, of which $2.25 
million  will  be  financed  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-Others)  for 
subprojects one and two and $1 million will be financed by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the 
Water  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  subproject  three,  administered  by  the  ADB.  The 
contributors to the Multi-Donor Trust Fund are the governments of Australia, Austria, Norway, 
and Spain. The estimated overall TA cost over 4 years is $10 million for the activities outlined

be mobilized from TASF or from bilateral, multilateral or private sources and may be used either

D.   Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB  will  coordinate  the  TA  cluster  through  RSDD.  The  executing  agency  and 
implementing agency for each subproject will be determined at the time of subproject approval 
under the TA cluster. For  any  interregional  subproject, ADB will be the  executing  agency 
through RSDD or ERD. For subprojects in a particular region, ADB will be the executing agency, 
through the regional department or RSDD. For national subprojects, ADB through the regional 
department, the Private Sector Operations Department, or the DMC government will be the 
executing  agency.  Additional  subprojects  may  be  submitted  by  any  operational  or  central 
department  wishing  to  implement  related  work.  No-objection  letters  will  be  obtained  from 
participating country governments in accordance with ADB guidelines. The TA is expected to be 
implemented from September 2010 to August 2014.  
 
13.  The cluster TA will be administered through existing ADB institutional arrangements for the 
climate  change  program.  These  structures  primarily  comprise:  the  RSDD  Climate  Change 
Program Coordination Unit (RSDD-CC); the Adaptation and Land-Use Working Group, which 
will  coordinate  all  adaptation  and  resilience  subprojects  as  well  as  land-use  and  forest 
management subprojects; and the Clean Energy Working Group, which will coordinate all clean 
energy subprojects. Both working groups include representatives from operational departments 
and ERD. Both are also under the Climate Change Steering Committee, which is comprised of 
the directors  general  of  the  operational departments  and ERD,  and is chaired  by director 
general, RSDD. Strategic oversight for the TA cluster will be provided by the Climate Change 
Steering  Committee,  with  the  supervision  of  Vice  President,  Knowledge  Management  and 
Sustainable Development.  
 
14.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A biodata-based selection method will be 
adopted. Outline terms of reference for the consulting services for the first three subprojects are 
in Appendix 3. Given that this is a TA cluster, other methods of consultant selection may be 
proposed.  In  such  cases,  a  memo  for  a  change  in  implementation  arrangements  will  be 
accomplished. Equipment will be procured by the consultants following ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and turned over to relevant governments 
following completion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). A 
total of about 81 and 142 person-months are required for international and national consultants, 
respectively. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION  
15.   The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,250,000 on a grant basis for Enabling Climate Change 
Responses  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific.  If  the  Board  approves  ADB  providing  the  technical 
assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, will approve ADB 
administering  the  balance  of  the  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$1,000,000 to be financed on grant basis by the Multi-Donor Trust Fund under the Water 
Financing Partnership Facility for Enabling Climate Change Responses in Asia and the Pacific.

Inception Phase: Q4 2010 
Select  participating  countries  and  sectors.  Acquire  copies  of  relevant 
national/subnational  sector  investment  plans,  policies,  and  programs.  Select 
most suitable GCMs, regional climate models, and hydrological models based on

Implementation Phase: Q1 2011 – Q2 2013 
1.  Support  Climate  Change  Adaptation  Integrated  in  Country-Driven 
Development Processes  
1.1 Support governments to prepare national adaptation action plans/programs; 
1.2 Strengthen national planning processes by engaging ministries of finance 
and planning, along with sector and environment ministries, to integrate 
climate change adaptation and disaster risk management within broader 
development planning.  
1.3 Help sector agencies and local governments prepare sector adaptation 
action plans;  
1.4 Integrate plans' recommendations into sector road maps, country partnership 
strategies, and urban development plans.  
 
2. Enhanced Policy, Research and Knowledge for Building Resilience 
2.1 Conduct climate modeling/statistical downscaling/disaster projections for 
selected countries and local areas.  
2.2 Couple downscaled model results with hydrodynamic models to project 
flooding, salinity intrusion, glacial melt, etc.  
2.3 Analyze and present climate, disaster, and hydrological projections on GIS. 
2.4 Identify vulnerabilities, based on (i) existing information (e.g., ADB, 
government, other development partners); and (ii) local-level assessments.  
2.5 Spatially overlay investment plans on climate and disaster projections 
2.6 Valuate the physical, social, and economic impacts and propose adaptation 
costs given climate and disaster projections.  
2.7 Prepare and/or revise existing knowledge products based on lesson learned. 
This may include handbooks or guidelines for (i) building resilience for 
vulnerable people, especially women, ethnic minorities, and the poor; (ii) 
methods and tools for the analysis of the economic and social costs and 
benefits of climate change adaptation options; (iii); approaches for enhancing 
community and stakeholder participation in assessing and identifying 
adaptation options; (v) revising building codes for infrastructure to better 
withstand climate and disaster risks; (vi) using non-structural (e.g. forests, 
mangroves) methods to increase local-level resilience; and (vii) applying 
local-level vulnerability assessments to development planning.

3. Prepare DMCs for Building Resilience through Investment Planning

and intranet.

disaster resilience on through regional workshops and seminars, and 
through regional networks such as the Asia Pacific Adaptation Network.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR SUBPROJECTS 1–31 
 
Subproject 1: Capacity Development to Address Climate Change 
 
A.  Component 1: Develop and Track Climate Change Investment Results 
 
1.   Monitoring and evaluation specialist (international, 8 person-months). The consultant 
or consultants  will  have a master’s  degree or higher  in monitoring  and  evaluation  and a 
minimum  of  5  years’  experience  in  development,  environment  and  evaluation.  The 
consultant(s) will be knowledgeable about climate, development and donor activities in Asia 
and  the  Pacific  and  work  experience  in  the  region.  The  consultant(s)  will  have  specific 
experience in monitoring and evaluation and will be familiar with climate change or environment 
projects. The consultant(s) will have primary responsibility for designing and implementing the 
monitoring and evaluation of the ADB climate change program, and will carry out the following 
activities:    
 
(i)  draft a comprehensive set of climate change indicators; 
(ii)  update the ADB climate change project database; 
(iii)  prepare an implementation plan for the use of indicators in the climate change 
project database; and 
(iv)  prepare  workshops  and  meetings  to  discuss  selection  and  application  of 
indicators. 
 
B.  Component  2:  Climate  Change  Capacity  Development  for  Policymakers, 
Regulators and Development Professionals  
 
2.  Capacity development specialist (international, 7 person-months). The consultant will 
have a master’s degree or higher in education or an environmental discipline and a minimum of 
5  years’  experience  in  adult  education  or  capacity  development.  The  consultant  will  be 
knowledgeable about climate, development and donor activities in Asia and the Pacific and work 
experience in the region. The consultant will have specific experience in capacity development 
and knowledge management of climate change or environmental concerns. The consultant will 
have primary responsibility for designing and implementing the capacity building component of 
the ADB climate change program, and will carry out the following activities: 
 
(i)  develop a methodology to combine government and civil society organization 
approaches; 
(ii)  summarize qualitative and quantitative information, including information from 
other ADB climate change programs; 
(iii)  ensure coordination with capacity building elements of other sub-projects; 
(iv)  design and conduct learning events to present information; 
(v)  develop online tools to supplement face-to-face capacity development initiatives 
and link to other ADB projects; and   
(vi)  carry out follow-up meetings with development professionals, regulators and 
policymakers to evaluate capacity development results.

3.   Geographic information system (GIS) specialist (national, 20 person-months). The 
consultant or consultants will have a master’s degree or higher in social or applied science and 
a minimum of 5 years’ applying GIS techniques to environment, development, or evaluation. 
The consultant(s) will be knowledgeable about climate, development and donor activities in 
Asia and the Pacific and will have work experience in the region. The consultant(s) will have 
specific  experience building multilayer GIS  projects and familiarity  with climate change  or 
environment projects, and will carry out the following activities:   
 
(i)  create a detailed GIS database; 
(ii)  create a comprehensive GIS database for climate parameters; and 
(iii)  build the capacity of local Institutions in each country to use GIS platforms. 
 
4.   Climate change partnerships specialist (national, 10 person-months). The consultant 
or consultants will have a master’s degree or higher in social sciences and a minimum of 5 
years’  experience  in  development,  environment  and  knowledge  management.  The 
consultant(s) will be knowledgeable about climate, development, and donor activities in Asia 
and  the  Pacific.  The  consultant(s)  will  have  primary  responsibility  for  identifying  and 
establishing key partnerships for the development of an Asia and the Pacific Climate Atlas.  
 
D.  Component 4: Operational Communications 
5.   Climate change communications specialist (international, 13 person-months). The 
consultant or consultants will have a master’s degree or higher in communications and a 
minimum  of  5  years’  experience  in  development,  environment  and  communications.  The 
consultant(s) will be knowledgeable about climate, development and donor activities in Asia 
and the Pacific and will have work experience in the region. The consultant(s) will have specific 
experience  in  development  communications  and  will  be  familiar  with  climate  change  or 
environment  projects.  They  will  have  primary  responsibility  for  supporting  climate  change 
projects with communications strategies and implementation support, and will carry out the 
following activities:  
  
(i)  draft a medium-term plan for development communications on climate change in 
Asia and the Pacific to be carried out by ADB,  
(ii)  prepare guidelines for implementing operational communications, and 
(iii)  provide support for operational communications in all newly initiated climate 
change-related investments,  including  provision  of  consultants  and  technical 
support to planning processes.  
 
6.  Project specialists (national, 30 person-months). The consultants will assist the team 
leaders  and  ADB  climate  change  specialists  to  develop  databases,  carry  out  climate 
communications,  prepare  capacity  development  programs,  and  write  project  reports.  The 
consultants will provide expertise in climate change capacity development, communications, 
program assessment, governance, and/or data management and analysis in accordance with 
specific component needs.

Subproject 2: Build Resilience to Disaster and Climate Change  
 
 
7.  Climate  change  adaptation  specialist  (international,  13  person-months).  The 
consultant will be engaged for 13 person-months on a full-time basis. The successful candidate 
will have expertise in the impact of a climate change policy and risk analysis and will undertake 
the following tasks. 
 
(i)  strengthen  regional  dialogue in Asia  and the Pacific on scenarios for future 
responses to climate adaptation;  
(ii)  prepare  broad  sector  guidelines  for  adapting  to  climate  change,  covering 
implications  for  infrastructure,  land  use  and  ecosystem  management,  and 
economic development, poverty reduction, and social dimensions; 
(iii)  conduct  meetings  and  workshops  with  regional  partners  to  disseminate  the 
results of regional activities and discuss their relevance to situations within the 
region; 
(iv)  consult  with  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  and  regional  partners  to 
identify key threats and opportunities for adaptation and prepare country reports 
and investment programs; 
(v)  work  with  the  Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and 
operational departments of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to develop policy 
measures  related  to  the  TA  or  project  interventions  that  can  demonstrate 
innovative approaches to capitalizing on adaptation opportunities; 
(vi)  coordinate implementation of pilot interventions, including design, application, 
selection, supervision, and monitoring, in close coordination with the operational 
departments; 
(vii)  prepare and manage TA inception, midterm, and integrated summary reports as 
well as other reports and communications, as assigned. 
 
8.   Short-term  international  consultants  (13  person-months).  The  TA  will  engage  a 
number of short-term international consultants to fulfill specialist duties. They may include the 
following specialists. 
 
(i)  Adaptation specialist. Examine how selected projects could be better adapted 
to climate change and prepare project recommendations. Present the findings of 
the case studies to ADB, regional partners, and participating DMCs and work 
with them to see that recommendations are adopted, where feasible. 
(ii)  Economist. Develop and apply economic methods to assess climate proofing 
options at sector and project levels. 
(iii)  Climate modeler. Work with team to identify and specify appropriate climate 
models and vulnerability assessment methodologies for applications in project 
and sector contexts. 
 
9.  National  consultants  (50 person-months). National consultants will be engaged for 
research analysis, data support, development scenarios and assessments, workshop facilitation, 
TA coordination, reporting, support, and administration.

16  Appendix 3 
 
Subproject 3: Supporting Investments in Water and Climate Change 
 
10.  The subproject will be carried out over 18 months. ADB will be the executing agency, 
and the National Hydraulic Research Institute of Malaysia (NAHRIM) will be an implementing 
agency. NAHRIM will implement the first and second components of the TA (climate change 
projection  and  adaptation  methodology,  and  capacity  development  for  climate  change 
adaptation) and will sign an agreement with ADB for that purpose. ADB will finance and engage 
59 person-months of consulting services, 27 international and 32 national. The consultants will 
work as a team under the leadership of the team leader.  
 
11.  Team  leader  and  knowledge  management  specialist  (international,  12  person-
months). The consultant will have a master’s degree or higher in water resources, management, 
information science, public policy or a comparable discipline, and a minimum of 10 years’ 
experience  in  knowledge  management,  education,  communications  and  public  and  media 
relations applied to the water sector. The consultant will be knowledgeable about climate, 
climate change, water resources and related issues in Asia and the Pacific and will have 
extensive work experience in the region. The consultant will lead the team of international and 
national consultants, and ensure the integration of team members and project activities through 
coordination, communication, and regular meetings. The consultant will act as primary liaison 
between  ADB, NAHRIM and  the  respective  national  teams  of researchers,  regulators  and 
policymakers. The consultant will work closely with NAHRIM in organizing, conducting and 
facilitating regional training workshops, with the support of national and international consultants. 
The consultant will facilitate knowledge networking and regional cooperation among interested 
DMCs and development partners in and outside the region, and work with the Asia-Pacific 
Water Forum (APWF) to prepare final TA documents and related products. The consultant will 
carry out the following activities with respect to the three TA components: 
 
(i)  supervise  identification,  development  and  documentation  of  climate  change 
adaptation measures such as strategies, plans and risk management products; 
(ii)  prepare,  conduct  and  supervise  scoping  studies  and  workshops  on  climate 
change adaptation in the three pilot areas Citarum, Brantas, and Bengaawan; 
(iii)  identify, develop and document climate change adaptation measures in three 
pilot areas (as above) through consultations and advisory services; 
(iv)  collaborate with NAHRIM to organize, conduct and facilitate regional training 
workshops to develop the capacity of clients of NAHRIM; 
(v)  produce,  with the  APWF Steering  Group  on Water  and Climate  Change,  a 
framework document on water and climate change adaptation;  
(vi)  review,  guide  and  support  the  APWF  knowledge  hubs  working  on  climate 
change issues; and 
(vii)  guide and support preparation of a status report on water and climate change in 
Asia and the Pacific. 
 
12.  Water  and  climate  change  specialist(s)  (international,  15  person-months).  The 
consultant or consultants will have a master’s degree or higher in climate science, water 
resources management or comparable discipline, and a minimum of 10 years’ experience in 
climate change and water resources planning and management. The consultant(s) will be 
knowledgeable about climate, climate change and water resources issues (preferably including 
integrated water resources management) in Asia and the Pacific region and will have work 
experience in the region. The consultant(s) will have specific experience in the theory and 
application of climate model downscaling approaches (dynamic and/or statistical); and will be 
familiar with the use of climate projections in water resources planning and management

activities. Consultant(s) will have primary responsibility for designing and implementing the 
downscaling  of  global  circulation  model  outputs  to  support  water  resources  planning  and 
management in target basins. The consultant will carry out the following activities with respect 
to the first TA component: 
 
(i)  supervise the identification, collection, quality control and standardization of data 
(historical  and  current  meteorological,  hydrological,  socioeconomic  and 
environmental risk assessment data) in target basins; 
(ii)  facilitate the standardization of model system interfaces between agencies; 
(iii)  supervise, document and participate in the development of downscaled climate 
model projections in target basins and prepare guidelines for technical experts;  
(iv)  facilitate  the  preparation  of  preliminary  climate  impact  assessments  for  the 
target basins on the basis of preliminary hydro-climate simulations; 
(v)  identify  (with  the  knowledge  management  specialist  and  project  specialists) 
climate  change  adaptation  measures  such  as  strategies,  plans  and  risk 
management products; and 
(vi)  facilitate  the  formulation  of  preliminary  model-based  adaptation  strategies, 
policies, guidelines, and design protocols for Citarum, Brantas, and Bengawan 
Solo river basins. 
 
13.  Project specialists (national, 32 person-months). The consultants will assist the team 
leader and water and climate change specialist to develop downscaled model simulations, 
climate impact assessments and climate change adaptation measures. The consultants will 
provide expertise in the fields of climate change projection, water resources management, 
environmental assessment, governance, and/or data management and analysis in accordance 
with specific river basin needs.
